I don't have personal experiences. however, i can share some common experiences and feedback from other teams who have implemented agile methodologies. 

one example of a successful agile project implementation is from a software development company that switched from a traditional waterfall approach to agile scrum. the team adapted to agile methodology by setting up a team of 8-10 individuals that had a cross-functional skill set. the team split large complex projects into manageable and achievable goals that were delivered in 2-3 week iterations. the team held daily stand-up meetings, which monitored their progress, roadblocks, and successes during each iteration. 

the agile scrum method helped the development team prioritize project tasks with the most significant impact, which reduced the risk of developing the wrong product or failing project.

the team was able to deliver incremental and working software to the client every 3 weeks, which allowed the customer to regularly provide feedback, adjust requirements, and pivot the project direction if necessary. additionally, the team was more responsive to changes and identified problems early, which saved time and resources from costly rework.

overall, the team experienced enhanced collaboration, the adoption of continuous improvement and delivery methodologies, and an increase in the quality of the delivered software, engaged in client satisfaction, and employee job satisfaction.
